snippet: JPMorgan Chase, which just reported a $2 billion trading loss, may have avoided financial disaster once, but that doesn’t make the bank immune.
abstract: Joe Nocera Op-Ed column suggests that JPMorgan Chase's $2 billion trading loss is sign that even an ostensibly well-run bank is not immune to the kinds of risky behavior that paves the road to financial meltdown; charges that the only way to get bank risk-taking under control is through a combination of tougher rules and transparency, precisely what the Dodd-Frank financial reform legislation aims to do.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase, which just reported a $2 billion trading loss, may have avoided financial disaster once, but that doesn’t make the bank immune.
